name: Out There Somewhere
description: You play an explorer stranded on a dangerous alien planet. Low on fuel, your only hope for escape is to find the planet’s core in this incredibly clever action-puzzle-platformer.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP and up Processor: 1.2 Ghz Memory: 1 GB RAM Graphics: 512 MB DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 300 MB available space
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 7 Processor: 2 Ghz Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: 1 GB DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 500 MB available space

reviews.review_text: Bought it for 17 cents during the summer sale, and out of all the games I bought (Garry's Mod, etc.) this was still my favorite. Very platform-y, and not only has great music but also great visuals. Would higly reccomend to anyone. Best 17 cents of my life.

A Spaceshooter and platformer game all rolled into one with great music. My only critique is that the game is relatively short.  If you're a fan of retro games that screams Nintendo, then this is definitely a game for you.         YouTube™ Video:

Totally surprised  I got this game by the bundle and first I didn't pay any attension on it, after I tried I cannot stop until finish the game! It's awesome!  Good: - Nice Character design and funny dialogue - Easy to catch up difficulty - Smart teleport gun puzzle - Simple but lovely graphics - Many archivement challenge as optional quests - Cost nearly free when it's on sales bundle and with trading cards  Bad: - Some abandon core place cannot back trace once missed out  Verdict: I feel both excited and guilty when I bought this great game at such low cost, must play!  Score: 9/10

I love this game, i recommend you buy it, now. Here is why: - really good soundtrack. - nifty pixelated visuals. - a well use of a simple game mechanic. It was so fun and enjoyable figuring out how to get to the other side. - smart and thoughtful level design. - it has a game of thrones reference. - perfect length, not the 'are you serious?! Is this the end of it??' short, and not the ' finally i finished this game i was getting bored ' long, it was just perfect. - it Costs 4 SR ( $1 ?), it should be more. - good soundtrack. Really good. - damn grigori is still ...  looking forward to your future work.

I beat this in less than an hour, but I picked it up in a bundle, so I was happy with that. :)  There were actually quite a few achievements that I could go back and get, but I probably won't with my backlog...  Reminds me of a quality NES game. Totally worth playing.

-Quick Review-   Out There Somewhere is a 2d puzzle platformer with a hint of old arcade-space-shooting at the start and end, making the nice sandwich, which is 'Out There Somewhere', developed by MiniBoss and released Mar 14, 2016.    -Detailed breakdown review-    Story:  You play as the Protagonist: Small-pixel-man-with-goldfish-bowl-on-head. Goldfish bowl head starts out by flying a ship trying to shoot down space-captain-who's-his-face.  (Can you tell none of the names stuck with me?)  While the story and plot are pretty forgettable the game controls aren't in the slightest.        Uploaded for the review - Captians Log, Star date; September 24 2016. I'm rendering my YouTube Review for Overwatch, and playing this.

Short, but hey it's two bucks. Gameplay is solid enough, and soundtrack is groovin'.

What can I say, is the best Brazilian puzzle platformer game. Cool gameplay, great music, entertaining puzzles at the right difficulty. The only con is that is a very short game, but at least is cheap. Definitely give it a try.

This is a very special platformer, because you have a teleport gun where you can shoot yourself over the screen. I find this idea very good, have never played I platformer like this. I can only recommend it for insanely -96% on sale. Buy it and get every achievement, it is worth it ;D

A short but very replayable game, especially for speedrunners and achievement hunters. The puzzles are devious but well designed and it's fun to use the teleport beam in clever ways. Some of the moves are pretty tricky to pull off with some very strict timing required and might be frustrating to inexperienced players. An experienced platformer player might get through this in about an hour- there's an achievement for speed-running it in less than 20 minutes and I managed to do it in 15 after some practice. At full price this is a good buy- at 19p in the sales, it's a no-brainer.

Very much recommended for the price. Sure the game is short, but with an amazing soundtrack and fun speedrunning challenges it  is  worth it. The 'Portal' concept in a 2D Platformer works brilliant, though it could've been used in way more fun ways. Like I said, it's worth for the small price and has some cool achievements to unlock. Recommended.

I wasn't expecting such a short gameplay, but in that hour and a half of gameplay I would say it's pretty packed with lots of puzzles and mechanics that will keep you wanting to keep going. Definately a game that requires complete focus and attention. With exhilarating music and retro graphics, this game is one to have in your library.   For about a quarter it's quite fun! Reminds me of an old arcade machine. Though, for a full price, I find that the $1.99 - $2.99 would suit the full price for the game better.   A great game, give it a try. It would be great to see a sequel.
Prety amazing game, it's like Portal having an affair with Metroid while Cave Story is watching.

A superb little game. Far more deserving of an indie game award than most that that actually receive them.  Don't be put of by the 8-bit retro visuals, or the overly cheap price tag. It is excellently designed and play tested to perfection. Unless you try to obtain all eleven cores you won't see just how true this is or how devious the developers have been!  Skill, not luck, rules in this game. Those who say otherwise are, in my view, mistaken... Experimentation is encouraged via 'seemingly' generous save points and it's best achievements will encourage you to play it several times with various completion aims in mind.  Five hours of real entertainment(if you push yourself to unlock all of it's secrets), something you don't always get from games costing many times as much!

Out There Somewhere is a 2014 platformer developed by unknown studio Miniboss. Another in a long line of Super Metroid lookalikes, it's enjoyed some success mainly due to being incredibly cheap.   But rather then simply riding on the coattails of Super Metroid (or Knytt, as it were), Out There Somewhere proves to be an enjoyable linear puzzle platformer, with a teleportation mechanic that features conservation of momentum similar to Portal (though the two have no real similarity beyond that). It's no metroidvania by any stretch of the imagination - most of the 'upgrades' are for an endgame effect that doesn't amount to much, and outside of that venture there's a total of 5 collectibles.   Instead of playing a retro pixel wannabe, I played a well-paced linear adventure, that nevertheless isn't perfect.   Most of the pacing is due to just how short it is - a playthrough won't run you longer than an hour (15 minutes if you know what you're doing) and the sheer lack of enemy variety becomes apparent on subsequent playthroughs. Add to that, that while the sprites are well designed and look quite nice on inspection (thankfully, not using the retro clause of pixel art to turn out subpar product) the very poorly handed tiling and lack of visual noise make the game's art look much more amateur than it really is.  This is most readily apparent during the intro and outro space battles. With a closer look, you can see the spaceships slowly rotating, the metal sheens and the sci fi aesthetic shining through, when taken as a whole it looks so empty and barren that you could mistake it for a first-year highschooler's Game Maker project.   These aren't particularly pressing issues; Out There Somewhere suffers from a lack of talking points. This isn't a particularly interesting game, and for all the secrets thrown into its linear world or the cool design of the protagonist, if this game hadn't gone for 20 cents then I wouldn't be recommending it. I wouldn't have even bought it. I've played Newgrounds games with more lasting value.   At $5, I wouldn't recommend it unless you're the type that goes for 100% completion. At the ridiculous sales price, I fully recommend Out There Somewhere as a snack-sized short romp to pace out the larger, more memorable videogames.

It was fun but short. Doesn't overstay it's welcome and I hope the devs make something of a larger scale for their next game. Also a bunch of hidden collectables that I'll most likely go back for to collect.

A 16-bit puzzle platformer that may be short but it packs quite a punch. It takes queues from many puzzle/platformers, such as: Portal, Half-Life, Braid, and VVVVVV, just to name a few. You play as a spaceship captain who, aided by helpful aliens must repair your ship to return out there somewhere. While the premise and the controls of the game are straight forward, this game is more challenging than meets the eye. If you enjoy bit graphics and are also a fan of platformers you should be playing it right now.

Fun little puzzle (sort of, I guess?) / platforming game. It's a good game for the price (and a steal at 19c as of this review). I mean, come on, you get to use a teleport gun. My only complaint is that you can't change the keybinds of the 3 buttons this game has to any of the non-letter keys (at least, that's my experience). I wanted to map jump to space, but unfortunately, the game has a list of pre-set keybinds which the player can set.

Sure, 19 cents it was a sweet deal, would be willing to pay 2 bucks for it. Super short, a bit too user friendly tutorial style for a full game.   I would have atleast liked 20 minutes of hard gameplay. Or a main boss you couldn't cheese him into only doing 1 attack.

This game is an absolute STEAL at $0.19! I can't stop playing it, would have gladly paid the regular price of $15 for this gem. The art-style is magnificent, the sound is excellent, and the challenge is just enough to engauge you without giving you a nose bleed. I can't say enough good things about this game. Get it now!!

Graphics: 8/10  Sound: 10/10  Puzzles: Brutal/10  Picked this up at a really good sale price. It's quite a challenge, and the music is some of the best I've heard in an indie puzzler. Quite fun overall. Think Metroid meets Portal, quite a combo.

The Good:  Very fun teleporting mechanic Retro graphics Funny little premise Charming old school music Cheap  The Bad:  Still pretty short even though it's cheap Potential to crash, but not gamebreaking due to many checkpoints  Out There Somewhere is really good, and I liked it a lot, but I sort of wish it was fleshed out more. The vast majority of the game is simple puzzle platforming with a teleport gun with a small scroll shooter segment at the beginning and end. I understand this is indie and short, but I liked it so much I wish there were more planets and scroll shooter segments to play. You encounter some alien species and a few power-ups for your ship, but it's only for one more shooter segment. I think it would be cool to extend this idea into a larger game with explorable planets and just more of the same fun.  I recommend this game because it's great and very fun, but it is short. Buy on sale if possible.

Great story and fun puzzle playthrough, but here are the things that really bugged me about the game: -Can't go to options while in game, have to save and exit and then you can access them at the main menu. -Doesn't have very good keyboard controls. I had to set my own from the start of the game, but once I got use to it it was fine. -I found the boss fight nearly impossible with keyboard controls because I was trying to dodge things while flying in all directions with arrow keys, and I had to also focus on shooting him with a different button. It would have been much easier with a controler. Besides all of that, it is a great little game, with interesting mecanics and good puzzles that aren't too difficult. For the current sale price of 0.19 cents, it's definitely worth it.

The game feels a lot like a student project more than a completed video game.  The story is almost non-existant, all you know is that you crash land on a planet and need to defeat some Russian named fellow.  The gameplay, while decent, feels very unoriginal. Sure the idea of a gun that teleports you to where it hits seems novel at first, but the game doesn't really do much to challenge the player with the ideas presented by the gun. Also, the only real areas that feel like you would benefit from understanding the game's mechanics are, oddly enough, the first few screens. You can shave off, roughly, 15 seconds there by using teleport and jumps and just knowing how the jumping as a whole works.  The absolute worst part of the game is the beginning and ending SHUMP sections though. The devs must not have known how to make a very good SHUMP because what they put forth was one of the worst I've ever experienced. The ship has can take several hits, which is nice because the hit detection can be a little wonky, but there's a lot of things that are just plain wrong. There's no invulnerablity at all after being hit in the ship, which means if you move incorrectly and get hit once you aren't given any time to regroup, you need to go into full panic mode. This also leads to another interesting glitch, which is also present in the normal sections of the game, if you get hit by something that explodes you take three hearts of damage. Be it a plane or missile in the SHUMP sections or the big monster's explosive shots. On the brightside, this allows you to finish the opening SHUMP section in 3 seconds as you only need to crash onto the planet and not beat the Russian guy.  The game is a good pickup if it's really cheap, because you won't be able to squeeze much more than 4 hours out of it, assuming you're attempting to 100% it, and those 4 hours will definitely not involve you being fully engrossed by the game.  If you want a Metroidvania game with more depth I recommend the Shantae games or Guacamelee.

Although this game is pretty short, the gameplay, price, and soundtrack make it absolutely wort it. The graphics were beautiful and the 8-bit soundtrack was literally music to my ears. I believe you will find this game most enjoyable indeed.

Out There Somewhere is a neat little 2D Game.  You can compare the design to the Metroid games and all in all the game structure really reminds me of 'You Have To Win The Game', what is, by the way, a really nice game.  A short assessment by myself:  Story: 8/10 It is the classical 'Hero-Kills-Evil' concept as it is in Megaman. Yuri is Megaman and Gregori is Dr. Wily.  Soundtrack: 100/10 The soundtrack fits perfect and is just genius.  Level Design: 10/10 It reminds of Metroid as I mentioned before.  Controls: 5/10 The control is the only thing I want to criticize. I highly recommend to play this game with a Game Pad, because it is a little bit awkward with the keyboard. (Compareable to 'Super Meat Boy' + Keyboard' just worse...!)  Difficulty: 10/10 Although you cannot adjust the difficulty in the game options you are able to play this game without getting frustrated. There are maybe some points where it can take a minute longer than usual but all in all the game is quiet easy. But it gets much more difficult when you try to find all cores or try to collect all steam achievements.

Nice and clever little platform/puzzle game. It will take 2 hours at best to finish it, but it has great replay value thanks to the secrets and the achievements. Considering the ridiculously low price, I recommend grabbing it to everyone.

FANTASTIC game for the modest price. Novel and fun concept. Nice pixel art. Cool main character. Ocassional humour. Included is the soundtrack which is a work of art in it's own right. One of the best '8 bit style' soundtracks I've ever heard  Short game (1-2 hours depending if you get stuck on any levels). Slightly unbalanced: generally slow paced puzzle levels followed by an insanely challenging and hectic space shooter boss (I had one health left for the finale and the game isn't very friendly with 'back tracking'  I would love to see future games featuring Yuri and Grigori :)

The game is quite interesting i have to say! - it really reminds me from a different game - i can't come up with the name for now - maybe later.  However it still plays differently. you start with a ship - and it is some sort of 'asteroids game' - eventually you will lose and u will crash - - you have to find the missing parts of the ship. You have a teleport gun - if u shoot - there will be a projectile flying - which will let you teleport if hit to a wall.  the game could be quite difficult too and with there puzzles. You also need intelligence and quick thinking in order to pass some area's. There are save stations/checkpoints throughout the level. It is also a little bit of 'metroidvania' that u have to go back point to point to do somethimg. but so far i know - you do not have a map which COULD be dissappointing the music is quite ok - it is 2D side scrolling 8 bit graphic style. monsters will respawn if u left the screen - the sound affects 'from guns, exploding, deaths, etc' are a little bit cheap - i mean, its a very very old sound effect. You can play with an xbox controller. Which actually plays better then on keyboard Default keyboard controls are weird. Z to teleport. X to jump. C to shoot. I think C should be jumping, Z to teleport and X to shoot. You can heal at checkpoints.  THE GAME IS OK BUT SHORT!   to make teleport useful - i do recommend using small hops, so that u can jump again once the projectile hit and u fly higher.  I give this a 6/10

The main mechanic of this game is the teleportation system which is really cool, it allows for some really interesting puzzles that may require you to think about for a bit before you can complete them. In the same way Portal requires you to think with portals, this game requires you to think with perfectly timed teleportation.   Would reccomend it at the normal price. This game is everything I have ever wanted in a short, cheap Metroidvania puzzle platformer. Don't buy it for $5, but for $0.19 it's a steal. A very cool and not at all gimmicky teleport gun mechanic, controller support, and a campaign that takes 90-120 min if you don't know what you're doing, 60-90 min to 100% if you know what you're doing, and 15-25 min to speedrun if you know what you're doing. I've played through the game start to finish about 5-7 times and I still don't have all the achievements. The collectibles are extremely fun and there's only one that I had to look up where to find it (the 11th core). All in all, I recommend this game to any fan of Metroidvania games and puzzle platformers. My only complaint is that backtracking is severely limited, but it's OK because the game is so short. Great replayability, great value, great game. 9/10.

Out There Somewhere is a very unique game, as you switch between genres. One part of it your in a spaceship flying around shooting everything up, the other part is you adventuring on a planet having to find your way past obsticals. Sometimes you have to stop and think about what to do next. Other times you just dodge your way past enemys. This game is over all very fun even though sometimes you will get stuck and get frustrated.

I picked this up on sale for about 20p, so I wasn't expecting much, so I was pleasently suprised at how fun and addictive it is. The controls can be a bit awkward at first, but stick with it, and before long you'll be teleporting, jumping, and zapping your way all over the place. It has a few tricky spots, but over all it wasn't too bad. So if you like platformers, I'd definitely advise you to pick this one up sometime.

Readers, please keep in mind my reviews are a hundred percent subjective. I got this game gifted. I found the mechanics original but felt like seeing glitched textures very early when I tried it. It doesn't really seem to be normal white square in some places. I'm not a big fan of space adventures neither so much of shoot them all games but there are always chances for original exeptions to occur. Super metroid is an exeption in my tastes that I enjoy playing but I am not a fan at all of megaman or Metal Slug (from which I do enjoy at least the work on animation) though they are references for a certain amount of players. I wouldn't say it's a bad game but I'm not sure to find much entertainement in it to my concern unfortunately. It's important for this kind of game to show flawless design nowadays to be enjoyable. I'm not fan of minimalism or drab graphics (unless it would correspond to a choice that would help immersion like horror or a bit psychological or mental insanity) such as Risk of rain either unless there would be various worlds and that's why I will prefer games like Wings of Vi (very nice mix of difficulty a bit of gore and attractive design that is unsurprisely very successfully working on me) or Shantae or Fidding Teddy 2 where I appreciate the gameplay feeling and the atmosphere as well as the games it is inspired from. Any games that refer too much to realistic gun crafting and certain kinds of propaganda will highly increase chances to earn my dislike. Actually it's hard to define what makes old school like games attractive. But there are some ingredients that will most often help to make them enjoyable to replay more than once. It still remains very subjective as we are not always in the mood for the same things as well as we don't want to eat the same things everyday.

Out There Somewhere is a platformer similar to VVVVV and You Have to Win the Game. Controls are very basic, with only three buttons: jump, portal gun, and gauss gun. You'll use your portal gun to cross chasms and navigate platforms and use the gauss gun (once you've found it) to shoot enemies. The rooms are challenging but never really frustrating or extremely hard and the game has a very short run time; you can probably get through the game in around an hour for your first play through. There's a small story in the game, but it's not the main focus and just provides a slight frame and motive for the main character.  The music is good, the controls are tight, and the game is fun to play through, even though it is a bit short.

Getting those may require more meticulous search or a walkthrough, but I don't see a point in doing that. 'Inspired by' Metroid and Cave Story doesn't mean it is even remotely comparable to those. Small bite-sized game and it also seems to be this development team's best effort out of all their project. I'd recommend this game with some qualifiers. It's short, at about an hour and a half, and maybe 2 hours if you search for every ship upgrade. The sprite art isn't particularly inspired and the environments are bland, but the games aesthetic isn't in any way bad. The music is along the same lines, passable, with really only one tune being moderately memorable. The teleportation mechanic here is used ocassionally well but never to any mindbending extent, though there is some promise in the nuances, and would be great to expand upon to make it more twitch based or have more intricare puzzles. It's definitely not a portal rip-off, and has plenty of its own imaginitive power, so hopefully that can be fleshed out if there's ever a sequel. Overall it was definitely worth 2 bucks.

Out There Somewhere is a great little indie game. I bought the game when it was on sale, however I regret that, as the game is well worth the 5 dollars it would normally cost. Out There Somewhere is well worth your time, money, and emotional investment.

I was looking at the sales on steam and found this game for around 0.20 USD, seeing how I had a few spare bucks on my steam wallet, I bought it thinking 'Why not?'.  Was it worth it? Absolutely.  This is a great game, the soundtrack is pretty good, the graphics look classic and neat, it's game mechanics are easy to understand and fun to use and Playing with an Xbox 360 controller makes it control amazingly. However, there're two main gripes I have with this game. First of all, the length, I played this completely blind, and I was able to complete it in about 2 hours, the story, and the game, feel pretty short. And second, the difficulty, It never gets or brutally hard or stupidly simple, but it's relatively easy, some of the 'Harder' screens in the game are pretty trivial, removing some of the challenge.  So overall, should you purchase this game? Yes... But I feel 5 dollars is a bit high, if you can find it discounted to any amount, pick it up as soon as you can, so you can waste a few hours shooting teleporting bullets and talking to aliens. 7/10

After enjoying completing the game with 100% and just some cards left to collect, I decided to give this fine piece of software a review.  So what's this game anyway? Basically it's a platformer, with minor Shoot'em Up parts both at the beginning and the end of the game. Armed with a teleport gun and a space suit you control Captain Yuri on his journey to defeat the evil Grigori.  Simple control scheme: arrow keys and 3 others, Z X C by default, Europeans might want to swap Z with Y prior to starting. The game does have controller support, I used a keyboard though and had no problems.  Over the course of my several playthroughs and experiments I only encountered 1 or 2 minor bugs you wouldn't experience without specifically looking for it. Even if, none of them was game breaking. Otherwise it's got smooth and clean animations, perfect hitboxes and overall fair difficulty. There's no real tutorial but is streamlined on directs you perfectly through the mechanics, the growing complexity should be no problem for the average player. If you want all achievements though, you're in for a tougher challenge, brace yourself and activate your thinker.  As for the design, it's an adorable small indie treasure, you won't get 10 hours of excitement but instead you'll get challenging fun packed into a small platformer. Nothing looks out of place, everything fits into this colourfully bright (but not bilindingly bright) small universe. Even the music is brilliant for such a small game, it's repetetive but it doesn't get boring, this way it's even fun waiting for the 'delay' Achievement while doing something else. Only downside is there's no transition when the BGM changes but hey, it's not like that would hurt anyone  My first playthrough took me an hour and roughly 15 minutes, the only thing that really got on my nerves was clicking through Yuris messages on my playthroughs after the first one...  Bottom line: whatever you pay, it's a bargain

In addition to all the other helpful reviews, I just want to add that Out There Somewhere is a well balanced game, not too hardcore, and the achievements are not painful but with a nice difficulty, if you're inclined to find all the powerups and stuff and go for 100% completion. Steam tells me it took me 9 hours, that was with several runs focusing on different achievements over the course of a few months and I enjoyed it.   Going through the game to see the ending takes about 1 to 1,5 hours on an average person's first playthrough, maybe more if you get stuck, but there are guides on Steam and on youtube just in case. The quick run achievement has a 20 minutes time limit, and that leaves quite some room for errors. Still it feels like an achievement when you did it. :)  The game never crashed and ran absolutely without performance problems on both my desktop (Win7 64bit) and an older singlecore laptop (Win7 32bit).

This is an awesome little game! It is a hidden little gem i picked up for $0.21. This is a puzzle platformer that is so fun because the puzzles are very satisfying to solve. At the beginning of the game i was a confused but I quickly picked up the game mechanics due to the games perfect learning curve. In other words when the game teaches a new mechanic, it starts off easy until you are familar with the mechanic, then harder till it becomes secondhand knowledge, and THEN thats when the game shows you the next new mechanic. Of course this is not to say that you will never be stumped at some parts, after all it is what makes a puzzle game a puzzle game and takes some creative thinking BUT is never anything ridiculous to solve. The main part about this game that is kept me so hooked were all the puzzles. The harder puzzles are extreamly satisfying to solve (plenty of 'OHHH!!' moments) and secrets are very rewarding to find. The puzzles in this game will never become stale, thats because even though the puzzles are essentially the same, the variations and new mechanics keep it very fun, enjoyable, and interesting to play. One more thing is that great soundtrack, props to them!  PROS -Great learning curve -Puzzles never get boring -New Mechanics add depth -Puzzles are very satisfying to solve -Puzzles are so clever (I know i've said it a bunch but I really love the puzzles!!!) -Great price -Secrets keep the game interesting -Never too easy or too hard -Awesome music to play to  CONS -None (I can't complain as the game has everything advertised plus much more and FAR exceded my expectations)  The game is short and can not really be a con for being so, as it cost me a mere $0.21. (But the game is so awesome that I wanted more)  The reason I have more than 4 hours is because I tried to get all the 'Abandoned Cores' and 'Ancient Artifacts'  Bottomline : get this game while it's still on sale, but if it's not... still get it cause it's awesome.  P.S The very beginning with the old arcade shooter mini game is an awesome little 'backstory' and an interesting way start off the game and if you survive long enough it will explain what the 'Abandoned Cores' do and what the boss looks like (you can't defeat him!)

Time of review: in 2 hours even, last room before the final boss; putting aside b/c bored and ♥♥♥♥ that last puzzle.  TL;DR: twitch based puzzle plafomer, think VVVVVV with fancier graphics, no exploration aspect, and different mechanics.  1st off: unlike what the tags currently say; this is not in any way a metroidvania, metroidvanias are distinguished by a big focus on exploration, ferreting out secrets, etc. You don't do that in OTS, the game is very linear, backtracking is impossible, etc. Its similar to a metroidvania in the sense that there is just 1 big map... but thats about it.  What the game actually is at heart is a fairly difficult puzzle platformer, with a big focus on the platforming, you WILL need some good twitch skills to get thru some of the mid/late game rooms. Think VVVVVV except instead of swapping gravity you jump, shoot, & teleport, and you'll have a good idea.  Oh, and also there are space shooter sequences right at the beginning & end.  If you want a cheap, short, challenging game to kill a weekend afternoon, this is a good buy. Just be aware its only around 2 hours or so for a playthru, the platforming is very twitch, and it aint got any exploration.

Out There Somewhere feels like an overly long tutorial that ends just when you get to the real game. It's disappointing, because there's definitely potential, but it just ends up being a waste of time. If this were a beta, or compressed a bit and given away as a demo, I'd be moderately impressed.

Out There Somewhere claims to have been inspired by Cave Story and Super Metroid, but those games raise expectations in my mind that I feel the game did not meet.  The game is far shorter than expected, my first playthrough lasting little more than an hour. It is also not nearly as varied as Cave Story and other Metroidvania-style games; you will spend the majority of the game with just your teleport gun and a normal gun. And while the puzzles involving the aforementioned teleport gun are definitely interesting, the claimed inspiritations led me to believe I would have a bigger arsenal at my disposal. Another issue I have with the game is the use of bullet hell-like portions of the game. These sections feel very out of place in a game that is otherwise essentially a 2D version of Portal.  Out There Somewhere is a decent game, considering the price, but the tauted inspirations to me implied a set of standards that the game did not deliver. Like I said above, this is 2D Portal. If that is what you want, then this game will do. But if you're looking for something Metroidvania-esque, look elsewhere.

Shovel knight did it right, but this has a lame story, dull characters, and nonexistanct plot.  4. Did I mention that the levels are repetative?  5. I beat the game in under an hour. I can't really recommend this game in good conscience. It took me just over an hour to beat, and I was never challenged mentally or reflexively. I tend to be a completionist, too. I mean, it's not  bad , it just wasn't very inspired.  The store page is perfectly happy to name drop both Cave Story and Super Metroid, despite those two games being nothing alike. Out There Somewhere is way, way more heavily influenced by Cave Story than Super Metroid. Expect an extremely linear adventure with a few relatively unimportant collectables lying one or two screens off the beaten path.  Almost nothing about this game is focused. The NPCs you meet almost never have anything interesting to say, and the environments you wander through are inconsequential. The core game mechanic is needlessly muddied when   you get a gun that lets you kill enemies  . 100%ing the game is impossible to do on your first playthrough.

If you like games that require precise jumping then you will probably like this one. I don't mind some of that but I got tired of repeating the same set of screens again and again since I'm not very good at this sort of game.  Having the game save after every screen would improve it greatly for me but I suppose most people would then claim its too easy.
